messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Naoshi fuchi
messages.msgSnippet: I can try. One thing to remember is that Ko-Mino kogai come in very odd sizes, particularly very narrow ones. This kogai could not be made into a kozuka
messages.messageBody:
I can try. One thing to remember is that Ko-Mino kogai come in very odd
sizes, particularly very narrow ones. This kogai could not be made into a
kozuka because it was too narrow. Also, Ko-Mino pieces are carved directly
from the metal - no inlays. They did overlays, which do not pop out. The
mimikaki was cut off and joined to the base of the decorative panel - the
line is still there. The kogai was very early, and so much of the work is
indistinct. Still an interesting piece.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: alchemyst [mailto:alchemyst@...]
Sent: Saturday, November 01, 2003 1:43 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Naoshi fuchi



Gordon -

You were correct, I totally missed the kogai/fuchi connection.
(Easy to do when you only have 6 functional brain cells, or is
it five???)

Seriously, I can't imagine the metal working skill to bend
a kogai around into a fuchi without damage; crimping the metal,
popping the inlay, etc. Is there any way you can post better
pics of the fuchi? I'd love to see more detail of the work.

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Naoshi fuchi
messages.msgSnippet: You might try reading the text, Rich. At least I think the information is there. First, it is not two fuchi, if you are referring to my article on Ko-Mino
messages.messageBody:
You might try reading the text, Rich. At least I think the information is
there. First, it is not two fuchi, if you are referring to my article on
Ko-Mino fittings, but one fuchi showing the front and back. This fuchi was
originally a kogai and has been re-worked (naoshi) as a fuchi. Unfortunately
the scan of the back didn’t come out clear enough to see the retained
kogai-ish sections.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: alchemyst [mailto:alchemyst@...]
Sent: Friday, October 31, 2003 6:15 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Naoshi fuchi



In the latest To-Ron, there are two fuchi labeled
as "naoshi fuchi". What does "naoshi" mean in this
context? I'm familiar with it from Naginata-naoshi, but
not in reference to fuchi.

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Naoshi fuchi
messages.msgSnippet: It s a fuchi that s made from another fitting, in this case a kogai.  It s the same as the usage of naoshi in kogai naoshi kozuka: a kozuka that is made out of
messages.messageBody:
It's a fuchi that's made from another fitting, in this case a kogai. It's the same as the usage of naoshi in kogai naoshi kozuka: a kozuka that is made out of a kogai. Or a naginata naoshi katana: a katana made from a naginata. Naoshi does literally mean repaired, but in this context maybe remade is closer to the idea. If a kogai was damaged, but the jita was still intact it could be remade into another useful fitting. I suppose that it might even be done if the kogai was fine but not needed for mounting. Probably a lot of naginata or nagamaki that were remade into katana and wakizashi didn't have anything wrong with them other than being old fashioned weapons that could be turned into something more useful through shortening and reshaping.
Jim

I guess they could be referring to a repaired fuchi.
Seems there would be better items to discuss tho.

Thanks
Rich S
